text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen today 
I am making a sweet snack it's something called

pang jee pang means flower and jee means to 
sear these are little chewy coconut pancakes

but today I'm gonna make mine with banana as 
well the most important ingredient in bang tea

is the flour okay and the flour that I'm using 
is glutinous rice flour it's basically far made

from sticky rice it comes in the back like this 
and it's usually green don't get the red one the

red one is regular rice flour and if you get 
that you're not going to have the same chewy

texture that's iconic to Bank D next let's look 
at the bananas now pang T does not need to have

bananas in them however I love adding bananas 
because it sort of softens the texture and adds

a sweet fruitiness to it that I think makes a big 
difference I'm using gluing my or Nahuatl bananas

and I'm using frozen ones today like this and you 
can get it at Asian grocery stores if you can get

fresh ones yay even better this is sort of the 
package that I get at my store yours might look

a little bit different there are some that are 
pre themed and those will have sort of a grayish

purple color don't use that one because those are 
not as right what you want to do is just saw them

and then mash them up you can use regular bananas 
as well and you get a very different flavor from

it so just make sure there are no big chunks 
little chunks are okay those are add texture

I'm using two types of coconut in this recipe dry 
shredded coconut make sure it's unsweetened in

Thailand we use fresh grated coconut but the dry 
ones will work just as well and the second one is

sort of my addition but it's also sort of a new 
trendy thing in Thailand is youth young coconut

meat now I don't have fresh young coconut meat 
but I do have the canned ones which work really

well the canned look like that and it'll say 
young coconut meat and the young coconut meat

will sort of add a different texture something 
that's softer yet it's still a little bit chewy

together with the dry shredded coconut it's just 
so much better the first thing I'm going to do is

I'm going to mix some coconut milk with some palm 
sugar now I'm using palm sugar because I love the

caramely butterscotchy flavor that it adds you 
could just use white sugar if you want it to just

going to put this on the stove on low just until 
the sugar is dissolved I'm not cooking it I'm not

reducing it in fact don't reduce it because you 
want to keep all that liquid and I just want to

make sure that the sugar is dissolved that's now 
a really delicious syrup just in and of itself

and I want to let this cool so it doesn't cook 
my flour when I add it now is the simplest part

you just mix all the other ingredients together 
so the flour if you find that all goodness rice

flour is just a little too chewy you can also 
do like 25% regular rice flour and you will get

something that's more tender I didn't use all 
four of the bananas this is probably just about

three so half a cup in total the shredded coconut 
young coconut just a little salt sharpen up the

sweetness a little okay so now that's cool I'm 
going to pour it all in the rice flour doesn't

absorb too much water so just a little bit of 
liquid as you can see can really moisten a whole

lot of flour now if at this point you feel that 
it's too thick you can add a little bit of liquid

but you don't want it running because you want 
to be able to control the shape and the size of

the pancake so if it's too runny then you get 
thin pancakes so ready to cook and you do want

non-stick pan for this because these things 
stick I mean they're sticky rice flour right

medium low heat you want it to cook slow and 
gentle because it's quite a thick batter and

I do just about a tablespoon of batter per piece 
and it should just have a gentle sizzle sound as

it hits the pan if it starts going Shh as soon as 
you hit it you probably over darken the bottoms

and you're just going for a nice golden brown 
color and easy way to test is to just you know

take a peek and if it's not brown then it's not 
ready let's see yeah that's what you're going for

modifications if this is a little too plain 
Jane for you you can use black sticky rice

flour which I can't find here but if you're in 
Thailand you can substitute 30% black sticky

rice flour and it'll turn a beautiful purple and 
it will have a really nice flavor or instead of

bananas you can do taro mash cooked taro or 
you can leave the bananas out altogether and

try the traditional original type which only 
has coconut scent so here they are my bank D

now here's a trick when they're still piping 
hot don't lay them on top of each other like

I did because they'll tend to stick together 
it you can still separate it but it's just

a bit harder let them cool down on their 
own a little bit and then you can arrange

it however you want let's take one here and if 
you can see the texture look how chewy that is

mmm so it's super dense too so that's why you 
want to make small small pieces it's not you

know the fluffy American pancakes this is 
like mochi all right let's give it a taste

takes a while to chew so chewy it's like nom 
nom nom those satisfying to eat and what I

love about adding the bananas is it softens 
the texture up a bit and it adds almost like

a slight acidity that makes it's not too sweet 
oh so good do give this a try and when you do

let me know how it goes send me a photo Facebook 
Twitter or Instagram and the recipe as always is

on hot Thai kitchen calm and I will see you 
next time for your next delicious Thai pin
